article.description:
Coming off a disheartening defeat against Florida and having endured the wrath of coach Gary Williams for
eight consecutive days, Maryland desperately needed a reason to feel
good.
article.headline: Terrapins shake off frustrations with 41-point victory
article.linkText: After a tough week, No. 22 Maryland enjoys easy victory
article.story: COLLEGE PARK, Md. (AP) -- Coming off a disheartening defeat against Florida and having endured the wrath of coach Gary Williams for eight consecutive days, Maryland desperately needed a reason to feel good. The Terrapins got one, at the expense of Maryland-Baltimore County. Ryan Randle scored 17 of his career-high 21 points in the second half as Maryland (No. 22 ESPN/USA Today; No. 23 Associated Press) returned from a lengthy layoff to defeat UMBC 101-60 Monday night. Drew Nicholas had 15 points for Maryland (5-3), playing for the first time since having its 87-game home non-conference winning streak snapped by Florida on Dec. 14. The defending NCAA champions never trailed in improving to 13-0 against UMBC. ''They had a tough week. They had exams, they had me after a loss,'' Williams said. ''I wanted them to enjoy it tonight, and I think they feel good about the way they played.'' Maryland led by 17 points at halftime, then pulled away in the second half. Six players scored in double figures, and Steve Blake had nine assists to become only the 23rd player in NCAA history to amass 800 for his career. The senior guard has 806. ''You get enjoyment out of winning, but you have this thing about playing well,'' Williams said. ''You don't just want to win, you want to look a certain way. I thought we had a good look tonight.'' After making only two baskets in the first 20 minutes, Randle scored Maryland's first 11 points after halftime to make it 56-28. The 6-foot-9 senior started the run with a three-point play, then added four consecutive baskets in the lane. ''Our big men just couldn't contend with him,'' UMBC coach Tom Sullivan said. ''Randle is a big-time player with the potential to be a pro.'' Randle made 10 of 15 shots from the field and had a team-high nine rebounds. P.J. Hatcher led UMBC (3-4) with 15 points. The Retrievers, who have lost four in a row, stayed within striking distance for the opening 15 minutes before succumbing to Maryland's superior speed, size and skill. ''They're very, very good. Obviously, they're too physical for us, and their pressing strategy really rattled our kids,'' Sullivan said. The Terrapins played without starting center Tahj Holden, who was excused from the team because of a death in the family. He was replaced by freshman Travis Garrison, who had eight points and eight rebounds in his first college start. Holden is expected back Sunday, when Maryland begins defense of its Atlantic Coast Conference regular season title against Georgia Tech. On this night, however, Holden wasn't needed. ''We wanted to get a big win,'' Blake said. ''Going into Christmas break, everyone is happy and feeling good. It's not just the win, but we played well, too.'' The addition of Garrison to a lineup with Nik Caner-Medley gave the Terrapins two freshmen starters for the first time since March 2000. Caner-Medley finished with 11 points and was instrumental in getting Maryland off to a solid start. The 6-8 forward made the game's first two baskets and scored on a soaring putback dunk to ignite a 10-1 run that put Maryland up 21-11. After his dunk, Caner-Medley pounded his chest in triumph. UMBC closed to 23-19 before Nicholas hit a 3-pointer and added two free throws to spark a 13-3 spree that gave the Terrapins a 14-point cushion. Nicholas scored 13 points in the first half to stake Maryland to a 45-28 lead.
